q: What are the symptoms of acne?
a: The symptoms of acne include spots, oily skin, and sometimes hot or painful skin.

q: What are the 6 main types of spots caused by acne?
a: The 6 main types of spots caused by acne are blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, nodules, and cysts.

q: What can I try if I have acne?
a: If you have acne, you can try not washing affected areas of skin more than twice a day, using a mild soap or cleanser, avoiding squeezing spots, using water-based non-comedogenic products, removing makeup before bed, using fragrance-free water-based emollients, exercising regularly, washing your hair regularly, and seeking advice from a pharmacist for mild acne.

q: When should I seek medical advice for acne?
a: You should seek medical advice for acne if over-the-counter treatments don't work, if you have moderate or severe acne, if you develop nodules or cysts, or if your acne is making you unhappy.

q: Why do I have acne?
a: Acne is most commonly linked to hormone changes during puberty, but it can start at any age. Other possible causes include genetics and hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle or pregnancy.

q: Who is affected by acne?
a: Acne is very common in teenagers and younger adults, affecting about 95% of people aged 11 to 30. It is most common in girls aged 14 to 17 and boys aged 16 to 19. Acne can also continue into adult life, with about 3% of adults having acne over the age of 35.

q: Are there any home remedies to treat acne?
a: There are several self-help techniques you can try, such as not washing affected areas of skin more than twice a day, using mild soap or cleanser, avoiding squeezing spots, and using water-based non-comedogenic products. However, if these do not work, it's best to seek medical advice.

q: What are the treatment options for severe acne?
a: If you have severe acne or if your acne appears on your chest and back, you may need treatment with antibiotics or stronger creams that are only available with a prescription.

q: Can diet or sexual activity cause acne?
a: There is no evidence that diet, poor hygiene, or sexual activity play a role in causing acne.

q: Is acne curable?
a: Acne cannot be cured, but it can be controlled with treatment. Treatments can take several months to work, but the results are usually good.

q: What are the different types of spots caused by acne?
a: There are 6 main types of spots caused by acne: blackheads, whiteheads, papules, pustules, nodules, and cysts.

q: What can I do if I have acne?
a: If you have acne, you can try not to wash affected areas of skin more than twice a day, use a mild soap or cleanser and lukewarm water, avoid trying to 'clean out' blackheads or squeeze spots, avoid oil-based skincare products, and remove makeup before going to bed.

q: How can I control my acne?
i: I have mild acne and want to control it
a: To control your mild acne, you can speak to a pharmacist for advice. They may recommend creams, lotions, or gels containing benzoyl peroxide. Be careful as it may bleach clothing. If your acne is severe or appears on your chest and back, you may need antibiotics or stronger creams prescribed by a doctor.

q: When should I seek medical advice for acne?
a: If you have mild acne, you can speak to a pharmacist for advice. However, if the acne is not controlled or makes you very unhappy, it is recommended to see a GP. You should also see a GP if you have moderate or severe acne, or if you develop nodules or cysts, as they need proper treatment to avoid scarring.

q: Why do I have acne?
a: Acne is most commonly linked to hormone level changes during puberty, but it can start at any age. Certain hormones cause the grease-producing glands in the skin to produce larger amounts of oil. This abnormal sebum, along with changes in the hair follicle lining and skin bacterium, leads to inflammation and pus.

q: Does diet play a role in acne?
a: There is no evidence that diet plays a role in acne. Other factors such as hormone levels and genetic predisposition are more closely linked to the development of acne.

q: Who is affected by acne?
a: Acne is very common in teenagers and younger adults, affecting about 95% of people aged 11 to 30 to some extent. It is most common in girls aged 14 to 17 and boys aged 16 to 19. Acne often improves as people get older, but it can continue into adulthood for some individuals.

q: Can exercising improve acne?
a: Regular exercise cannot improve acne directly, but it can boost your mood and improve your self-esteem. It is recommended to shower as soon as possible after exercising to prevent sweat from irritating the skin.

q: Are poor hygiene and sexual activity related to acne?
a: There is no evidence to suggest that poor hygiene or sexual activity play a role in the development of acne. The main factors are hormone levels and genetic predisposition.

q: Can acne be cured?
a: Acne cannot be cured, but it can be controlled with proper treatment. Treatments may take several months to work, but the results are usually good. It is important to follow a consistent skincare routine and avoid picking or squeezing the spots to prevent scarring.
